+Ichu Pichu  I'm going to respond to your last point first, war is brutal. 
Simply put, if you don't want your people to get hurt or killed, then don't 
start wars. But when you do start a war, you should know that the stronger 
side will prevail and will wind up killing more people of the weaker side.

If a small country right now attacks your country and a war erupts between 
your country and theirs, who do you think will stand to lose more people? 
That's how wars work. So when you start a war with a stronger country than 
your own, don't expect the end results to be fair, because they won't be. 
When the Palastenians attack the Israelese, they should know that they will 
suffer more casualties, because they are the weaker of the two countries.

With regard to your second point, you are right, Caucasians don't qualify 
for affirmative action here either, just as Asians and Middle Easterners 
don't. Before affirmative action came into play, a very small fraction of 
Blacks and Mexicans ever got into colleges. They established affirmative 
action, in order to give those extremely disadvantaged races a bigger 
opportunity to get into colleges, because most were not entering colleges 
and winding up in lives of crimes instead. And they were trying to take 
these two races out of their lives of crimes and put them into a more 
productive part of society. Because Asians have always shown to be better 
in schools than other races, they have disqualified themselves from being 
eligible for affirmative action. But you need not get all worked up over 
this, because as you know Caucasions and middle easterners are not eligible 
for affirmative action either. As far as grants are concerned, I have been 
out of school for many years now and I am still paying off my student loan 
which started out as $28000 and has now arisen to over $90,000 because of 
the interest accrued. I also thought that I could pay off part of my 
student loan and get out of paying the rest. But after they started 
garnishing my paychecks, I learned otherwise. So there is no free money 
that is being given away to anyone. If there is, us Caucasions don't see it 
either.

And with regard to your first point, if indeed a small majority of people 
in your country are killing and eating dogs and cats, then you must make 
that known. Because that is not how the rest of the world is perceiving it. 
If you can eradicate the practice of killing dogs and cats in your country 
altogether, then you will go back to being perceived as the humane and 
good-hearted people that you always were considered before. Nobody dares to 
treat a humane person as inhumane and vice versa.

Let me first say I have always had a pet dog and I love them more than I 
love most people. Some animals are more intelligent than others. For 
example a pig is much smarter than a dog or cat, or even most primates for 
that matter. However, how animals are classified in human minds, be it as 
food or as pets, is completely dependent on culture. One persons pet can be 
another person's food. The distinction is wholly subjective to the people 
making the distinction. When you take the human subjectivity out of the 
conversation your left with the fact that anyone who eats animal meat is a 
complacent part of a process called slaughter. That is why we call the 
place where animals are killed and converted into eye pleasing chunks and 
slices slaughter houses. Take a few minutes and watch videos of the 
slaughter process for the animals you eat daily. Before anyone should judge 
be sure your not guilty yourself. If you want to save one animal from the 
menu you must save them all from it. Otherwise your opinion on the matter 
is culturally biased and your view is racist. Unfortunately, living things 
must gain sustenance from things that are alive or once were. That is the 
nature of life as we know it. We can obtain our nutritional needs from 
plants and fish, and be all the more healthy for it, without making rivers 
of tortured blood flow from the dinner table. If you love dogs remember all 
animals have the same feelings as dogs.﻿

1910 photo taken in Paris.
Source: Wikimedia Commons
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Grande_Boucherie_Canine_a_Paris.jpg


Let us explore this dog-eating habit country by country.  Let's begin 
with.....

USA

The terms "sausage" and "dog" have been used as synonyms since 1884 and 
accusations that dog meat was used in the making of sausages dated to at 
least 1845.  These accusations were sometimes justified.


France

Dog meat has only become taboo in France today.  In the past, it was not 
so.  See the photo above of a dog butcher in Paris taken in 1910.  French 
Press described dog meat in the late 19th century as "beautiful and light" 
and ran stories of people buying dog meat in France.


Germany

Germans have eaten dog meat since the time of Frederick the Great and it's 
commonly called "blockade mutton".  Dog meat continued to be eaten in the 
1920s.  Even a meat inspection law in 1937 mentioned the following animals 
as commonly used for meat: "pigs, dogs, boars, foxes, badgers..."   It was 
only in 1986 that Germany prohibited the consumption of dog meat.


Belgium

In the early 20th century, dog meat was widely sold in Belgium.  The 
average price was 12 francs a kilo ($1.30 per pound) in 1916.  Even the 
Council of the Veterinary School of Belgium recommended dog meat for human 
food.


Poland 

In Poland, the meat of dogs is culturally not eaten; it's considered taboo. 
 However, in some rural areas in Poland, there is a tradition of eating dog 
fat in place of lard.  Dog fat is considered beneficial to one's health, 
particularly the lungs.  As recently as 2009, a farm near Częstochowa was 
discovered to keep dogs which were subsequently killed and turned into lard.

Switzerland

Switzerland has a long tradition of eating dog meat.  Eating dog meat is 
not illegal in Switzerland.  Less than 7 years ago, Switzerland enacted a 
law merely to prohibit the production of food from dog meat for commercial 
purposes.  This is provided for in Ordinance of 23 November 2005 on food of 
animal origin.

1910 photo taken in Paris.
Source: Wikimedia Commons
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Grande_Boucherie_Canine_a_Paris.jpg


Let us explore this dog-eating habit country by country.  Let's begin 
with.....

USA

The terms "sausage" and "dog" have been used as synonyms since 1884 and 
accusations that dog meat was used in the making of sausages dated to at 
least 1845.  These accusations were sometimes justified.


France

Dog meat has only become taboo in France today.  In the past, it was not 
so.  See the photo above of a dog butcher in Paris taken in 1910.  French 
Press described dog meat in the late 19th century as "beautiful and light" 
and ran stories of people buying dog meat in France.


Germany

Germans have eaten dog meat since the time of Frederick the Great and it's 
commonly called "blockade mutton".  Dog meat continued to be eaten in the 
1920s.  Even a meat inspection law in 1937 mentioned the following animals 
as commonly used for meat: "pigs, dogs, boars, foxes, badgers..."   It was 
only in 1986 that Germany prohibited the consumption of dog meat.


Belgium

In the early 20th century, dog meat was widely sold in Belgium.  The 
average price was 12 francs a kilo ($1.30 per pound) in 1916.  Even the 
Council of the Veterinary School of Belgium recommended dog meat for human 
food.


Poland 

In Poland, the meat of dogs is culturally not eaten; it's considered taboo. 
 However, in some rural areas in Poland, there is a tradition of eating dog 
fat in place of lard.  Dog fat is considered beneficial to one's health, 
particularly the lungs.  As recently as 2009, a farm near Częstochowa was 
discovered to keep dogs which were subsequently killed and turned into lard.

Switzerland

Switzerland has a long tradition of eating dog meat.  Eating dog meat is 
not illegal in Switzerland.  Less than 7 years ago, Switzerland enacted a 
law merely to prohibit the production of food from dog meat for commercial 
purposes.  This is provided for in Ordinance of 23 November 2005 on food of 
animal origin.  ﻿

Publicado em 27/06/2014
Each year, the Yulin Lychee Dog Meat Festival takes place on a midsummer's 
day in southern China, where an estimated 10,000 dogs are eaten annually. 
The festival has a long history, but it has been getting increased 
attention in recent times from animal rights activists, especially after 
reports that traders were threatening to kill dogs on the spot if dog 
lovers didn't immediately buy them. LinkAsia's Mark Dreyer looks at the 
reactions to the controversy on social media.

Thumbnail Photo: A vendor (C) lifts a dog as he negotiates with animal 
activists offering to buy the dogs to stop them from being eaten ahead of 
the annual dog meat festival in Yulin, Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region 
June 20, 2014. The festival, scheduled on June 21 as in previous years to 
mark the summer solstice, in southern Chinese city of Yulin, has drawn 
fierce protests from animal welfare groups and pet owners, who urge the 
local government to ban the long-standing tradition. According to animal 
welfare activists, about 10, 000 dogs will be consumed on that day, Xinhua 
News Agency reported. REUTERS/Stringer

Visit our homepage at http://linkasia.org
